name: Acid Drop
notes: PAL-only; puzzle game; last game released. Atari 2600s stopped being manufactured

name: Air Raid
notes: Only 13 copies known to exist[citation needed]

name: Alien's Return
notes: Primarily a PAL release. Released in NTSC format as E.T Go Home

name: Bachelorette Party
notes: Released as a 2-in-1 cart with Burning Desire

name: Berenstain Bears
notes: Kid Vid Voice Module required to function

name: Burning Desire
notes: Released as a 2-in-1 cart with Bachelorette Party

name: Challenge
notes: Released in NTSC format by Zellers

name: Confrontation
notes: Only originally available directly from Answer Software for a short time.

name: Cosmic Corridor
notes: NTSC release of Bit Corporation's Space Tunnel

name: Creature Strike
notes: Released as part of a "2 PAK SPECIAL"[14]

name: Cruise Missile
notes: Same game as Exocet released by Panda

name: Deadly Discs
notes: reissue of M Network's Tron: Deadly Discs

name: Dishaster
notes: Zimag's NTSC release of Bit Corporation's Dancing Plate

name: Donkey Kong
notes: licensed by Nintendo Co., Ltd; reissued by Atari in 1988 (CX-26143)

name: Donkey Kong Junior
notes: licensed by Nintendo Co., Ltd; reissued by Atari in 1988 (CX-26144)

name: Dungeon Master
notes: Released as part of a "2 pak special"[14]

name: Entombed
notes: Researchers going through the game code in the 2010s have been unable to figure out how the game's maze-generating algorithm managed to consistently generate playable mazes. The original coder says he got it from another programmer who wrote it while drunk.

name: Exocet
notes: Same game as Cruise Missile released by Froggo

name: Fighter Pilot
notes: PAL release of Tomcat: The F-14 Fighter Simulator

name: Fisher Price
notes: Same game as Aquatak, Sea Hunt and Scuba Diver

name: Gamma-Attack
notes: Only one copy known to exist. It was listed on eBay for $500,000 but never sold.

name: Gigolo
notes: Released as a 2-in-1 cart with Bachelor Party

name: I Want My Mommy
notes: NTSC release of Bit Corporation's Open Sesame

name: Inca Gold
notes: Zeller's NTSC release of Funvision's Inca Gold

name: Jungle Fever
notes: Released as a 2-in-1 cart with Knight on the Town

name: Knight on the Town
notes: Released as a 2-in-1 cart with Jungle Fever

name: Lady in Wading
notes: Released as a 2-in-1 cart with Beat 'Em & Eat 'Em

name: Lochjaw
notes: Later released by Apollo as Shark Attack

name: Masters of the Universe: The Power of He-Man
MegaBoy
notes: The cartridge, the only known 64k Atari 2600 game, came with a Brazilian portable console also called Megaboy.[15]

name: Mouse Trap
notes: licensed by Exidy; reissued by Atari in 1988 (CX-26146)

name: Nightmare
notes: Panda released this game as Stunt Man

name: Pac-Kong
notes: A later PAL release of Funvision's Inca Gold

name: Phantom-Panzer
notes: Quelle's PAL release of Bit Corporation's Phantom Tank

name: Philly Flasher
notes: Released as a 2-in-1 cart with Cathouse Blues

name: Red Sea Crossing
notes: Only available through mail order from a magazine. 100 copies were apparently produced but only 2 have been found.[17]

name: Sea Hunt
notes: Froggo's release of Panda's Scuba Diver

name: Shark Attack
notes: A re-release of Lochjaw, which has subtle differences

name: The Smurfs Save the Day[18]
notes: Kid Vid Voice Module required to function

name: Snail Against Squirrel
notes: PAL release. Released in NTSC format as Squirrel

name: Space Adventure
notes: Zellers' release of 20th Century Fox's Flash Gordon

name: Space Canyon
notes: Panda's release of Apollo's Space Cavern

name: Space Shuttle: A Journey into Space
Spiderdroid
notes: Froggo's release of Parker Brothers' Amidar

name: Spider Maze
notes: K-Tel Vision's NTSC release of Funvision's Inca Gold

name: Star Wars Return of the Jedi: Death Star Battle
Star Wars: The Empire Strikes Back
Stunt Man
notes: Panda's NTSC release of Sancho's Nightmare

name: Sub-Scan
notes: Sega's release of its Deep Scan arcade game

name: Tank Brigade
notes: Panda's NTSC release of Bit Corporation's Phantom Tank

name: Tanks But No Tanks
notes: Zimag's NTSC release of Bit Corporation's Phantom Tank

name: Task Force
notes: Froggo's release of Spectravision's Gangster Alley

name: Time Warp
notes: Zellers' NTSC release of Funvision's Time Warp

name: Tomcat: The F-14 Fighter Simulator AKA Dan Kitchen's Tomcat: The F-14 Fighter Simulator
Tooth Protectors
notes: Was only available via mail order from Johnson & Johnson

name: Tron: Deadly Discs
notes: conversion of Intellivision Tron Deadly Discs

name: Venture
notes: licensed by Exidy; reissued by Atari in 1988 (CX-26145)

name: Vulture Attack
notes: This is K-Tel Vision's release of Ultravision's Condor Attack game program

name: War Zone
notes: PAL release of 20th Century Fox's M*A*S*H

name: Weltraumtunnel (Space Tunnel)
notes: PAL-Release - Quelle-variant is a BitCorp-clone; also known e.g. as Ataque Laser, Innerspace, Laser Volley, Laser Gate, Laser Gates

name: X-man
notes: Adult-themed game unrelated to the X-Men.[19]
